Hi Mike

> The approach with HAL is that the meaning of a resource and its
> properties are given to it by the link relation which led to its
> discovery. So if you follow a link relation 'user' and you get back a
> representation of a resource that includes the property 'age' - you
> know the meaning of that property is 'the age of this user (resource)'
> because the user rel has documentation which tells you that.

We have recently been going through this discussion on another mailing list 
and, yes, I agree with you that this approach works for a lot of 
applications. But for some uses link-rels just ain't enough - and Linked 
Data seems to be one of them. I am no expert at LD but I believe I 
understand the triple <subject, predicate, object> conecpt - which is very 
much similar to link-rels <origin-resource, relation, target-resource>.

In HAL's world view a relation tells not only HOW a resource is related to 
another - it also tells WHAT the other resource is. But some relations do 
not work like this.

Take the link-rel or predicate "likes", meaning the subject X likes the 
object Y, or in HAL/REST - resource X has a "likes" relation to resource Y. 
What does that tell about Y? Nothing. The Y resource can be a dog, a movie, 
a place - anything - a client following "likes" won't have a clue about the 
type of resource in the other end, and a property called "Age" could refer 
to just about anything.

> buf if you
> desperately felt the need to have your HAL representations explicitly
> typed so that they can 'stand on their own' and not require a
> preceding link relation, then you could use a profile link to do this
> job (a la dret's ongoing work). I think that's a poor design decision,
> but it is perfectly possible.

Yes. It is perfectly possible and solves the problem above. But it is not 
fair to call it a poor design decision - there are certain use cases that 
requires it - Linked Data seems to be one of them.

The conflict seems to stem from two different view points: data as plain 
messages in a well known interaction versus data as typed resources taking 
part of the semantic web.
